entry.title: BTP CIS Provisioning Job fail with error
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,
When I scheduled the provisioning job in Cloud identity services with IAS as source data(reads Users and Groups) and BTP Subaccount as Target system. The Provisioning Job fail with the attached error, Could you suggest how to resolve the issue.

I've attached the source system transformation

entry.title: Roadmap for Joule studio
entry.content:
Can anyone explain the roadmap for Joule studio?

IT is unclear to me as what is available and what is yet to be implemented in Joule Studio.

Is AI agent available?

Can Joule Studio be integrated to S4HANA private cloud?

Can Joule Studio be integrated to on premise system?

entry.title: Cannot receive SMS verification code for SAP Trial account in China
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community, I am currently stuck in the final step of creating my SAP Trial account and would appreciate any help from the community. Issue: After entering my mobile number for verification, I consistently get the error message: "We cannot send you a code. Please check your phone number and try again." I do not receive the SMS code at all. What I have already tried/troubleshooted: To solve this, I have already taken the following steps, but without success: Correct Format: I ensured my number is in the correct international format: (e.g., +8613811122233), without any dashes or spaces. Different Browsers: I tried using different browsers (Chrome, Edge) and also in incognito/private mode. Cleared Cache: I cleared my browser cache and cookies.

#https://account.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial/#/home/tria

entry.title: Does SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Support OCR-based Invoice Document Capture Without Ariba Central?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I have a question regarding invoice processing capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Does SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud have a built-in feature to scan and capture supplier invoices (PDF or paper format) using OCR technology and import them as documents into the system?

I'm aware that integrating with SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management is one option for this functionality. However, I'm wondering if this can be achieved using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud as a standalone solution, without requiring additional Ariba licensing.

Any insights or guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Vibe Coding with MCP Servers & SAP AI Core: Toward "Coding by Conversation"
entry.content:
Over the past few months, I’ve explored vibe coding — a workflow where you prompt the AI, it generates code, and you iterate. Fast and interactive, yes — but in enterprise projects, context and governance are critical. Without them, hallucinations and mismatched code structures quickly emerge.

This is where MCP servers (Model Context Protocol) and SAP AI Core become essential. Tools like fiori server and cap server allow AI assistants to understand your CDS models, Fiori metadata, and application structure — enabling contextual, reliable code generation.

In this blog, we’ll explore the architecture, practical usage, and enterprise best practices that make AI-assisted coding robust and production-ready.

What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding is a transformative approach to software development — essentially, coding by conversation.

  • You describe requirements in natural language.
  • The AI assistant interprets your intent and proposes code patches, scaffolding, or tests.
  • You review, refine, and approve the generated output.

The power of vibe coding lies in freeing developers from repetitive boilerplate tasks, allowing them to focus on high-value work like architecture, user experience, and business logic.

SAP’s reference architecture for vibe coding with Cline + SAP AI Core demonstrates how AI-assisted development can be safe, repeatable, and fully aligned with enterprise standards — turning AI from a helper into a structured development partner.

Core Principles from the SAP Architecture

From the reference architecture, five principles stand out:

  1. Prompt-Driven Development – Express features in natural language, and let the system automatically generate the initial scaffolding.
  2. Context Engineering – Supply LLMs with only the necessary structural context, such as APIs, CDS models, or MCP metadata.
  3. AI-Assisted Test-First Approach – Begin by generating tests, then guide the AI to produce code that fulfills those requirements.
  4. Human-in-the-Loop Governance – Developers retain responsibility for ensuring compliance, performance, and security.

Introducing MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) acts as the bridge between your project and the AI assistant.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is designed to act as a powerful bridge between your project and the AI assistant, ensuring that development is not just driven by prompts but also grounded in real project context. Instead of leaving the AI to guess or hallucinate about how your application is structured, MCP Servers provide it with a deep, contextual understanding of your project.

They expose key elements such as metadata, annotations, models, services, entities, relationships, and queries. This allows the AI to reason intelligently about your project’s architecture, whether it’s related to the user interface, the underlying data definitions, or the service layer.

With MCP servers running, your AI assistant doesn’t hallucinate blindly — it knows your project structure.

Architecture in Action: Cline + SAP AI Core + MCP

Here’s how the pieces fit:

  1. Cline –Your coding agent inside the IDE, mediating prompts, code diffs, and project changes.
  2. SAP AI Core – Hosts the foundation models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini) in a governed, enterprise-ready environment.
  3. MCP Servers – mcp server expose structured context:
    • UI annotations, metadata, and manifest structure
    • Style guides and constraints
    • CDS entities and services

Workflow:

  • You prompt: “Create a ListReport for SalesOrder with a status field.”
  • AI (via MCP) inspects CDS models and annotations.
  • AI generates the CDS extension, Fiori annotations, and manifest changes.
  • You review, test, and deploy.

This architecture transforms AI coding from a “toy experiment” into a repeatable, enterprise-grade engineering practice.

How to Get SAP AI Core Credentials

  1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Navigate to AI Core: Services → Instances and Subscriptions → AI Core
  3. Create Service Key:
    • Go to your AI Core service instance
    • Create a new service key
    • Copy the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, url, serviceurls)
  4. Configure Authentication URL: Usually follows pattern https://{subdomain}.authentication.{region}.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  5. Set Base URL: Typically https://api.ai.ml.hana.ondemand.com (check your service key for the exact URL)
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
SAP_AI_CORE_AUTH_URL=https://your-subdomain.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
SAP_AI_CORE_BASE_URL=https://base-ai-core-url
SAP_AI_CORE_RESOURCE_GROUP=your-resource-group

Refer to the screenshot below, which shows how we subscribed to the SAP AI Launchpad application to deploy our model according to the use case. We also created an SAP AI Core instance to obtain the necessary key details required for configuration in the Cline client.

Cline Configuration

  1. Install the Cline extension in VS Code
  2. Open Cline settings
  3. Configure these fields:
    • API Provider: Select "SAP AI Core"
    • Client ID: .clientid
    • Client Secret: .clientsecret
    • Base URL: .serviceurls.AI_API_URL
    • Auth URL: .url
    • AI Core Resource Group: Extract UUID from .appname (first part before the !)

       4. Test with a simple query to make sure it works

Add Server Configurations

To enable AI-assisted coding with full context, add the following server configurations to your cline_mcp_settings.json file. This configuration allows Cline to connect to the MCP servers that expose structured information about your project, including CDS models, Fiori metadata, manifest files, and coding style constraints. By providing these settings, you ensure that the AI assistant can:

  • Understand project structure: MCP servers give the AI visibility into your CDS entities, services, and UI annotations, allowing it to generate code that aligns with your existing models.
  • Follow enterprise standards: Style guides, naming conventions, and other constraints are passed through MCP servers, ensuring that generated code adheres to your organization’s best practices.
  • Generate context-aware code: Instead of generic snippets, the AI can create extensions, annotations, or manifests that fit seamlessly into your project.
  • Improve efficiency and reduce errors: By providing a structured context, the AI minimizes mismatches and hallucinations, letting developers focus on architecture, business logic, and user experience rather than repetitive boilerplate.

With the server configurations in place, Cline can interact with MCP servers in real time, making AI-assisted coding a safe, reliable, and enterprise-ready process.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "cds-mcp",
      "args": [],
      "env": {},
    }
  }
}

Set Guardrails with Cline Rules (How-To)

Purpose: Provide persistent, project-level guidance — covering scope, coding style, documentation standards, and more — that’s always active in your workspace.

Cline Rules act as a continuous, automated advisor for your development team. By defining guardrails, you ensure that AI-assisted coding adheres to enterprise standards and project-specific conventions. This prevents inconsistent implementations, reduces technical debt, and maintains code quality across the team.

  1. Create a Rule File
    1. In Cline’s Rules tab, click “+” or use the command: /newrule.
    2. Save as a single file: .clinerules at the repo root, or use a folder-based setup .clinerules/ for multiple rules.
  2. Recommended Folder Structure
your-project/
├── .clinerules/
│   ├── 01-project.md      
│   ├── 02-coding.md
│   └── 03-documentation.md  
├── docs/
  • Each file addresses a specific aspect of project guidance: project scope, coding standards, and documentation expectations.

Example Prompt Flow

You: "Initialise an empty SAP CAP application in this folder."
AI: The empty CAP application has been successfully initialised in the current folder

 

You: "Generate an entities sales and sales order items"
AI: The entities is successfully created.

Result: you stay focused on implementing business logic and refining the user experience, while the AI assistant handles all the scaffolding, boilerplate, and repetitive code generation.

Open the Cline application and start the conversation with the above commands — this is where vibe coding truly comes alive, as your AI assistant (powered by MCP servers and SAP AI Core) begins generating context-aware code that you review, refine, and evolve into enterprise-ready solutions.

Once you select the Plan and submit the prompt, Cline (with MCP servers in the loop) interprets your intent, fetches the right CAP/Fiori context, and proposes structured code changes that you can review and refine into a production-ready solution.

You will now see a fully scaffolded CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application generated — with entities, services, and annotations created automatically based on your prompt, thanks to the MCP servers providing structured context to the AI assistant.

Benefits & Caution

Benefits

  • Faster Prototyping and Scaffolding – Quickly generate CAP entities, Fiori views, and annotations without manual boilerplate work.
  • Reduced Hallucinations – Structured context from MCP servers ensures AI proposals are relevant and accurate.
  • Freed Mental Bandwidth – Focus on UX, domain logic, and performance optimization, while AI handles repetitive scaffolding.
  • Aligned with SAP Standards & Governance – Generated code respects enterprise best practices and architectural guidelines.

Caution

  • MCP Servers Are Evolving – Always review AI-generated code before deployment.
  • Complex Business Logic Needs Oversight – Human expertise is essential for transactional integrity, security, and edge-case handling.
  • Prompt Precision Matters – Well-crafted prompts yield better, more reliable results.
  • Governance Remains Your Responsibility – Testing, security, and compliance cannot be fully delegated to AI.

Conclusion

Vibe coding isn’t just about writing code faster — it’s about reimagining how we build enterprise software. By combining AI assistants, SAP AI Core, and MCP servers, we provide AI the context it needs to act as a true development partner.

This approach lets developers move beyond boilerplate work and focus on what matters most: architecture, business logic, user experience, and innovation

Human expertise remains essential. Governance, compliance, performance tuning, and creativity stay firmly in the developer’s hands. But with vibe coding, tedious and repetitive tasks are no longer blockers — they’re delegated.

As these patterns mature, this may be remembered as the moment enterprise development evolved from “writing code” to “designing conversations.” The future of coding in SAP isn’t just AI-assisted — it’s context-aware, collaborative, and human-centered.

entry.title: CAP 'Build Your First App with CAP' bookshop tutorial : SAP Fiori UI does not work
entry.content:
Hi,

I'm following the jumpstart bookshop tutorial 'Build Your First App with CAP':
https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/get-started/in-a-nutshell#jumpstart 

Everything has been installed and worked until the SAP Fiori UI part
https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/get-started/in-a-nutshell#fiori 

As described there, one could take the Fiori UI bookshop example from https://github.com/capire/bookstore/tree/main
I executed these steps

  1. setup done as described here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/get-started/#setup (from jumpstart)

  2. 'git clone https://github.com/capire/bookstore' (and execute the further commands in bookstore folder)

  3.  'npm i' successfully executed (after I added line "//npm.pkg.github.com/:_authToken=<<MY_GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN_FOR_PACKAGE_READ>>" to ~/.npmrc file)
  4. 'cds watch' => this command resulted in the following error

$: ~/bookstore cds watch

cds serve all --with-mocks --in-memory?
( live reload enabled for browsers )
___________________________

[cds] - bootstrapping from { file: 'server.js' }
[ERROR] srv/mashup.cds:11:28-31: Artifact “sap.capire.reviews.api” has not been found (in using:“reviews”)

Thank you for further help/advice to get this tutorial part running.

entry.title: OAuth2.0 Authentication for S4HC APIs
entry.content:
Hi Experts,
We are trying to set up non-user interactive OAuth2.0 Authentication for S4HC APIs, to access the APIs from third party applications
Can this be achieved without BTP?
Also are the Standard APIs restricted to use only OAuth2.0 Access code flow? or can other grant types be used?


Cause when I try to set up inbound OAuth2.0 Clients in my customizing tenant, the grant type is disabled and only shows Authorization code + PKCE


And if i were to add my OAuth2.0 Provider, the autogenerated inbound Oauth2.0 clients have the grant type SAML2 Bearer Assertion. Are these the only two grant types that can be configured in the Tenant?
If BTP is my only option, could you please direct me to blogs with steps to set up Oauth2.0 client credentials in cockpit (Cloud foundry) and s4hana cloud instance and finally test from postman?
@Andre_Fischer @Sandra_Rossi @Amin_Omidy @quovadis

entry.title: BTP Trial - Error starting instances: 'insufficient resources: containers'
entry.content:
Hello,
In my SAP BTP Trial environment, I cannot start my application. When I click Start, the app immediately stops, and I receive the following error:

Error starting instances: 'insufficient resources: containers'

This has been happening for the last few days and prevents me from running the application.

Details:

  • Global Account: Trial account in region US10

  • Space: dev

  • Application name: cloud-tpm-srv

    I have attached a screenshot from the terminal for reference.

    Has anyone experienced this issue, and is there a known workaround or fix?

    Thank you in advance for your help!

SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime and environment

entry.title: 'Build Your First App with CAP' bookshop tutorial : Deploy to BTP Cloud Foundry fails (mbt build)
entry.content:
Hi,

I was following the jumpstart bookshop tutorial 'Build Your First App with CAP':
https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/get-started/in-a-nutshell#jumpstart

After I got a workaround for a bug of the Fiori bookshop sample (see https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/cap-build-your-first-app-with-cap-bookshop-tutorial-sap-fiori-ui-does-not/qaq-p/14231262), I have the bookshop sample running on localhost.

Now I want to deploy the full-stack CAP application on BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime, as described here:
https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/to-cf

Steps I followed:

  1. Prerequisites, all done => https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/to-cf#prerequisites
  2. Prepare for Production, steps below done => https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/to-cf#prepare-for-production
    • Step 1. (cds add hana)
    • Step 2. (cds add xsuaa)
    • Step 3. (cds add mta)
    • Step 5. (cds add workzone)
  3. Build and Deploy section => https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/to-cf#build-and-deploy
    • cf login step, done
    • cds up => this command resulted in the following error (entire console output at the bottom in [1])

[2025-10-01 15:47:14] INFO executing the "npm run build" command...
npm error Missing script: "build"
npm error
npm error To see a list of scripts, run:
npm error npm run
npm error A complete log of this run can be found in: /Users/d032153/.npm/_logs/2025-10-01T13_47_14_690Z-debug-0.log
[2025-10-01 15:47:14] ERROR could not build the "bookstoreadminauthors" module: could not execute the "npm run build" command: exit status 1
make: *** [bookstoreadminauthors] Error 1
[2025-10-01 15:47:14] ERROR could not build the MTA project: could not execute the "make -f Makefile_20251001154658.mta p=cf mtar=mta.tar strict=true mode= t=\"gen\"" command: exit status 2
Error: could not build the MTA project: could not execute the "make -f Makefile_20251001154658.mta p=cf mtar=mta.tar strict=true mode= t=\"gen\"" command: exit status 2
Command failed: mbt build -t gen --mtar mta.tar

Thank you, if someone has an idea what is wrong here and how fix it

Additional remark:
The "mbt build" works if I skip step 5. (cds add workzone) in the above 'Prepare for Production' steps

[1] Entire output of 'cds up'

$: ~/bookstore cds up
mbt build -t gen --mtar mta.tar
[2025-10-01 15:46:58] INFO Cloud MTA Build Tool version 1.2.34

[2025-10-01 15:46:58] INFO done

entry.title: Need Guidance for SAP C_ABAPD_2507 Exam Preparation
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m currently preparing for the SAP C ABAPD 2507 exam and I’m looking for the most reliable and updated practice questions to support my preparation.

If anyone can share study tips, recommended resources, or guidance on how to structure an effective study plan, it would be a huge help. I really want to make sure I’m focusing on the right material and practicing with questions that reflect the real exam format.

Thanks a lot in advance for your support and suggestions.

entry.title: Difficulty Triggering Workflow in SuccessFactors When Data Is Auto-Posted from BTP
entry.content:
Hi All,

I’m working on an integration where contract end data is auto-posted from SAP BTP to SuccessFactors (SF) . The data is being posted into the Resignation portlet, and I want to trigger a workflow in SF when this happens. But, the workflow is not getting triggered when the data is posted from BTP. 

Thanks,
Sakshi

entry.title: SAP Business One Hana FP2011, Web Browser
entry.content:
Hello Expert,

We are experiencing frequent crashes of the SAP Business One application.
We have limited the add-on to certain databases, but the problem persists and requires manual restarting of the Browser Access Gatekeeper service several times a day.
This intermittent problem is preventing us from working.
Please help.

entry.content:

entry.title: Question: When will my blog post become visible on SAP Community?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
I submitted a blog post this past Sunday (October 5, 2025). As far as I know, blog posts on SAP Community go through a moderation process before being published.

How long does this usually take? My post hasn't been published yet.
Did I possibly miss something, or should I just wait a bit longer?

Thanks in advance 🙏

entry.title: Questions on using Terraform with SAP BTP Trial Account
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am following the Discovery Center mission “Implement Observability in a Full-Stack CAP Application Following SAP BTP Developer’s Guide” and have a few questions regarding the optional section “Set up your subaccount in SAP BTP using Terraform provider for SAP BTP”.

A few weeks ago, I completed an introduction to Terraform and then did some hands-on practice setting up a Trial Account with developer tools. However, I got stuck on a few points, which I’ve now encountered again, and would really appreciate some clarification.

Here’s my setup and questions:

  • I’m trying to set up a Trial BTP Account using Terraform
  • When creating the Cloud Foundry environment instance, it’s automatically created with Org Memory set to 0 MB, and I can’t modify it due to restrictions (as mentioned in a previous Q&A). Is this a trial account limitation, or am I missing something?
  • In the Discovery Center mission, the .tfvars file for step 1 requires a custom_idp URL. Starting from a (trial) global account without any existing subaccount, how can I obtain this information? When I do this manually in the trial subaccount, I subscribe to the Cloud Identity Services (default plan) and then establish a trust configuration.

Maybe I’m misunderstanding part of the setup, any insights or experience you can share would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance

entry.title: SAP Hana DB Triggers
entry.content:
Hello gurus, 

Does the .hdbtrigger provide details of what has been changed? And if yes how to access this?

Below is my trigger, and I want the "CONTEXT" to contain info on what has been changed

 
TRIGGER "TR_TB_COSTCENTERTEXT_CREATE"
  AFTER INSERT ON "TB_COSTCENTERTEXT"
  REFERENCING NEW ROW NewRow
  FOR EACH ROW
  BEGIN
   
    INSERT INTO TB_CHANGELOG
    (
      "ID",
      "SOURCETABLE",
      "SOURCE",
      "ACTION",
      "LOGTIME",
      "CONTEXT",
      "STATUS")
      VALUES
      (
        SYSUUID,
        'TB_COSTCENTERTEXT',
        :NewRow."source",
        'INSERT',
        NOW(),
        ---> <what was changed> <----,
        'NEW'
      );
  END;
 
Update: 
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/using-hana-database-triggers-to-capture-selected-column-updates/ba-p/13159575
I found this approach using "REFERENCING OLD ROW OldRow, NEW ROW NewRow" and then compare the columns 1 by 1.. But that is quit a big task when you have many columns to track.
Any smarter solution available?

entry.title: Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable in Product API error
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and trying to perform a POST operation using the Product (API_PRODUCT_2) API.
However, I’m receiving the following error response:

{
  "error": {
    "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
    "message": "Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable",
    "target": "_ProductPurchaseOrderText(Product='102010000009',TextObjectType='BEST',Language='EN')",
    "details": [
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductProcurement"
      },
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductPlant(Product='102010000009',Plant='CN7A')/_ProductPlantProcurement"
      }
    ],
    "innererror": {
      "ErrorDetails": {
        "@SAP__common.Application": {
          "ComponentId": "LO-MD-MM",
          "ServiceRepository": "SRVD_A2X",
          "ServiceId": "API_PRODUCT_2",
          "ServiceVersion": "0001"
        },
        "@SAP__common.TransactionId": "86545C3DDA130010E0068E7D20C1703B",
        "@SAP__common.Timestamp": "20251009154237.258522",
        "@SAP__common.ErrorResolution": {
          "Analysis": "Use ADT feed reader 'SAP Gateway Error Log' or run transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG on SAP Gateway hub system and search for entries with the timestamp above for more details",
          "Note": "See SAP Note 1797736 for error analysis"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

My Question:

  • Why are these entities (PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT, PRODUCTPROCUREMENT, PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT) not maintainable through the post API?

  • Are there any restrictions in the Public Cloud Edition for maintaining these sub-entities via API?

  • Is there an alternative API or approach to update these product procurement or purchase order text details?

 

I’ve already checked the payload structure and API reference documentation, and the JSON is valid. The base product entity is being read successfully — the error occurs only during the POST operation.

Any insights or SAP Notes related to this behavior would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance,
Janarthanan R.
